title: Friday, 4th October 2019

Anyway, here's the story: https://www.ft.com...-9743-db5a370481bc

BE11:08am

Bob Dudley will step down as chief executive of BP next year after leading the company through a turbulent decade, taking the UK energy major from near collapse after the Deepwater Horizon disaster back to a position of growth.

After a four-decade career at BP, 64-year-old Mr Dudley will be replaced in February by Bernard Looney, the company’s head of exploration and production and a longtime frontrunner for the post.

Helge Lund was appointed BP chairman in early 2019 and has prioritised succession planning. 

Viking1 Morning

He did a pretty good stint to be fair.

Plato the Cook Morning, btw

And I'm sure the weekend press will be full of Bob anecdotes, of which there's plenty. Such as the one about the Shell merger that never happened.

BP PLC (BP.:LSE): Last: 488.45, up 3.55 (+0.73%), High: 491.45, Low: 486.15, Volume: 5.24m

tangledodyssey Life Beyond Petroleum!

Here's Barclays.

BE11:10am

New CEO Bernard Looney: The man to win over the millennials

11:10 am
BE11:10am

Uh ............ huh.

JP11:10am

What.

BE11:10am

BP has confirmed that CEO Bob Dudley is to step down next year after nearly 10 years in the role. Bernard Looney, current head of the upstream, to take over from February 2020. This should not come as a surprise to the market given Mr Looney's role in modernising the upstream for BP and driving the digital agenda with a vision that the industry and the company are seen as cool, clean and low carbon. As the sense of urgency around greenhouse gas mitigation grows, the debate over what role the energy stocks play in such a world has become increasingly polarized. As we highlighted in our note “Engaging Gen Z key to re-rating” (17 April 2019) we think it is important for the share price that BP is seen as a leader in this area. Given the drive for digital solutions and the work on reducing carbon emissions it is likely that the appointment of Mr Looney as CEO may accelerate the journey that BP is on regarding the energy transition. We rate the shares Overweight with a 700p/sh price target.

11:10 am
JP11:10am

I can't tell you much about millennials, being one.

BE11:10am

Engaging Gen Z. You heard.

JP11:11am

But what I can tell you, is that they're not too keen on non-renewable, I mean sorry, energy, companies.

tangledodyssey Omg, not someone else with a mission to "win over millennials"!
11:11 am

This is not millennials, despite what the title said. Your generation is dead to us already.

They're mad keen on fossil fuels.

11:12 am

GBKrona sounds Looney (pun intended)
JP11:13am

He recently doubled down on British energy giant BP and now owns over one million shares. But rather than dwell on its sagging, crude-dependent stock chart, he’s betting on its hydrogen fuel cells and enjoying its 6% dividend yield while he waits for the company to recover.

“They have important intellectual property in that area,” he says of the cells, which create electricity by using hydrogen as fuel, a technology Wertheim believes is the future of both air and road transportation. “We’re going to move to a hydrogen economy.”

BE11:19am

The upshot of which is:

2s10s #EquityJitters , #NFP : Yesterday US Service PMI roiled the equity markets but they shrugged it off; gold and bonds still signalling risk off though. I wonder what will happen with payrolls this afternoon.
11:19 am
BE11:19am

The FCA found that competition is not working well for all consumers in these markets. It sets out concerns about how pricing in these markets leads to consumers who do not switch or negotiate with their provider paying high prices for their insurance.

The FCA estimates that around 6 million policyholders pay high prices and are not getting a good deal on their insurance. If those customers paying high premiums paid the average premium for their risk they could save around £1.2 billion a year. This affects all types of customers. The FCA estimates this includes 1 in 3 people who are potentially vulnerable.

BE11:19am

In particular, the FCA found that:

Insurers often sell policies at a discount to new customers and increase premiums when customers renew, targeting increases at those less likely to switch.
Longstanding customers pay more on average, but even some people who switch pay higher prices.
From the FCA’s consumer research, 1 in 3 consumers who paid high premiums showed at least one characteristic of vulnerability, such as having lower financial capability. For consumers who bought combined contents and building insurance, lower income consumers (below £30,000) pay higher margins than those with higher incomes.
People who pay high premiums are less likely to understand insurance or the impact that renewing has on their premium.
Most firms, when setting a price, include their expectations of whether a customer will switch or pay an increased price. This is not made clear to the customer.
Firms engage in a range of practices to raise barriers to switching.
Many consumers who switch or negotiate their premium can get a good deal.

BE11:19am

So .........

11:19 am
BE11:20am

The FCA is undertaking a range of activities in order to address the problems it has identified. Through new rules introduced in 2017, the FCA has already improved transparency on renewal for general insurance policies which has delivered significant savings to customers.

The FCA will also continue its work to ensure firms improve the oversight of their pricing practices and deliver the changes required following other recent policy changes.

The FCA is also considering remedies to:

Tackle high premiums for consumers – this could include banning or restricting practices like raising prices for consumers who renew year on year or requiring firms to automatically move consumers to cheaper equivalent deals.
Stop practices that could discourage switching – including restricting the way that firms use automatic renewal.
Make firms be clear and transparent in their dealings with consumers - including improvements to the way firms communicate with their customers. The FCA is also considering whether firms should publish information about price differentials between their customers.
Harness the benefits of innovation in the longer-term, so that general insurance markets benefit positively from technological developments including Open Finance.

Viking1 Fox , FCA doing the damage
BE11:20am

Note! Important! Interim report.

JP11:20am

It seems to me that insurance is just another in a long line of businesses that relies on human apathy.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

Yep.

JP11:20am

No different to most cloud companies (consumer facing at least) or banking.

BE11:21am

It's remarkable the number of financial services that take a profit based on price creep.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Or in the case of things like mortgages, price spike.

Forester With responsibility for for 4 cars and 2 households switching all this every year is a complete ballache. I would happily pay a bit more for a 5 yr fixed deal etc!
JP11:22am

CPG companies used to be the same.

JP11:22am

Control distribution = pricing power.

11:22 am
JP11:22am

Which might explain a lot of why those companies have struggled recently.

JP11:22am

Anyway, I'm going off topic. Here's Peel Hunt:

JP11:23am

The FCA published its interim report on General Insurance pricing practices in Motor and Home which focuses on: a) consumer outcomes from pricing practices; b) the fairness of pricing practices; and c) the impact of pricing practices on competition. Issues that are being reviewed include the impact of dual pricing/loyalty premium (price walking), pricing transparency, consumer shop around behaviour (particularly at point of renewal), the impact add-ons have on pricing, competition and the fair treatment of (vulnerable) customers

11:23 am
JP11:23am

Remedies: In a £18bn market for Motor and Home insurance the FCA found that 6m policyholders paid high prices and would save £1.2bn if they paid the average risk. Across the whole market this would suggest an impact of c7%. The FCA has concluded that insurance pricing is not working for all consumers and is proposing a number of remedies to further improve price transparency at renewal. Remedies include: limiting charging higher prices for consumers that do not actively switch; a ban on auto-renewal or making it opt in only; automatic switching to lower priced products providing equivalent cover; active marketing of alternative (better priced) deals such as in the energy market; expanding product governance at firms; and insurers explaining reasons for price increases.

JP11:23am

What the FCA is not proposing is strict pricing regulation (caps or rate bands) in the insurance market. Also, there the FCA is not requiring the industry to sell multi-year contracts or requiring a single switching & renewal period. At this point, there are also no remedies relating to ancillary products or instalment income which is reassuring. Our first take, is that the FCA is taking a thorough review of pricing behaviour and is cautious about implementing strict pricing controls. Those insurers that compete to win active switchers via PCW’s (ADM, HSTG) or are active in niche markets (SABRE), are in a better position than many of their peers. Brokers are also likely to change their pricing behaviour.

BE11:23am

Apathy creep the pricing strategy of our age. Ask anyone how much they're paying for TV or broadband, for example, and they'll probably be wrong by about 50% because they haven't been paying close attention since signing up.

11:24 am
JP11:24am

I'm a case in point. Pay far too much for BT, can't be arsed to complain.

BE11:24am

I reiterate, though, interim report. We'll see what the final looks like in Q1 once the lobbyists get in there.

JP11:24am

The CBA industry we should call it.

11:24 am
JP11:24am

Yep, fair point BE.

BE11:26am

FCA reforms could put at risk the AA's Roadside income per customer
of £165 (front book £100 vs back book £180+) and retention rates of 80%.

11:26 am
BE11:27am

And Barclays.

BE11:27am

This development comes at a time when the AA is looking to rapidly grow its motor book (through lower prices for new customers), and increase profitability over time through customer retention & higher renewal prices – as is the current industry model. The potential remedies, proposed by the FCA, could make achieving these goals more difficult, and also challenge the profitability of the existing back-book of policies in the short term, in our view. Insurance is 17% of group EBITDA (FY19A).

Motor, home, breakdown and other insurance products are within scope of this study, but roadside assistance policies are not specifically under review by the FCA – to our knowledge. However, we think it reasonable to assume the potential ramifications could extend to the roadside business, given it has the same regulator and similarities in its business model. The combined Roadside business (B2C+B2B+driving schools) is 83% of group EBITDA.

JP11:27am

(@Graunch -- to your point had a real issue recently trying to claim a sole occupier discount on my council tax. Took me like 3 weeks and an hour on the phone.)

Viking1 Fox , markets talking about Saga’s Saviour launch
11:28 am
BE11:28am

If the FCA were to pursue more interventionist policies, the impact would be industry wide and could see prices rise for first year customers.

BE11:28am

In the longer term this could reduce incentives to switch provider, increase retention rates, lead to more sustainable revenue streams and lower costs of customer acquisition. The interim transition period however, could be painful as higher profits are currently made from the back-book; which is the case in motor/home insurance as well as roadside assistance policies.

BE11:28am

The AA is already limiting renewal pricing in its older roadside policies to around inflation levels [c2%].

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Overall, the precise outcomes of the study won’t be known until Q1 2020 and the market was aware of the potentially negative consequences of the study, in our view. Still, we expect the shares to come under further pressure. The direction of travel outlined by the FCA is clear and is likely to be a drag on profitability, in our view. On yesterday’s close price, the shares trade on CY20e 8.5x EV/EBITDA, 11.2x EV/EBITA with a 7.1% FCF to EV yield.

BE11:31am

Risks to industry profitability. We have previously considered the range of options available to the FCA, and in our view all of these appear to be being considered. These include intervention to prevent price increases on renewals, actions to improve transparency, and actions to improve oversight. In our view it is now clear that the FCA is looking to intervene in some form, and therefore the structure of the industry is likely to change. We believe Home insurance sees the greatest cross subsidy between new and existing customers, but motor may also be affected. Given that the FCA is highlighting that customers may be collectively overpaying by £1.2bn, it is likely in our view that it will aim to reduce this, suggesting a smaller industry profit pool.
 Companies more at risk. In our view companies with longer tenured customers are more likely to be benefitting from this phenomenon today, and we also see the problem as greater in Home insurance. This suggests a risk for DLG and SAGA in our view, although we note that both companies have been taking actions to reduce this effect in recent years. Aviva, RSA, and Ageas could also be affected, although we note that these are more diversified groups. We do also see risk for Admiral, for Hastings we believe the cross subsidy it enjoys today will be lower due to its more recent growth and PCW focus. Without knowing more detail about the actions the FCA may take, it is very difficult to estimate the quantum of any impact in our view.

cracklenpop I'm switching energy suppliers at the mo and their main aim seems to be signing you up for stuff you don't want or need eg smart meters.
BE11:32am

And Credit Suisse.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Overall this is negative for the UK P&C industry, margins will be negatively impacted especially as insurers reduce the “excessive” margins charged on loyal customers. Some insurers have already moved ahead of the curve by ensuring vulnerable customers do not price walk into higher charges, or by introducing multi-year policies. Insurers are likely to reduce the initial discounts offered on new business, but the reduction in renewal premiums will be the dominant factor. Moreover, the industry’s ability to increase new business premiums at a time of heightened public focus on switching/negotiating insurance prices is low.
■ Soft pricing cycle likely to continue for longer, in our view. In our recent initiation we noted that regulatory intervention into the market would put downward pressure on pricing, leading to an extension of the current soft pricing cycle in UK motor. We think recent signs of the cycle improving are now likely to be revered as insurers cut prices on their renewal book. Remember renewal policies count for ~70% of business and so is the dominant factor in determining average premium inflation. Claims inflation in UK motor remains elevated at ~5% across the industry vs average premium declines of ~2% at H1 19 yoy.

Tom Dalgleish @Forester, there is an opportunity to aggregate accounts and obligations into a mega website but vendors won't cooperate
JP11:32am

A short thing from Shore:

BE11:33am

Home insurers are more exposed than motor insurers as the relative price differences between new and renewal premiums are larger, partly due to the lack of price comparison website (PCW) penetration. From our coverage this means DLGD.L and SAGAG.L potentially have higher exposure than HSTG.L and ADML.L. With RSA.L and AV.L having lower exposure based on their earnings mix from UK P&C. We note that both DLG.L and SAGA.L had already moved to address some of the concerns (restricting margins on renewals, introducing multi-year policies). We note that the perceived exposure of DLG.L based on mix of home and motor insurance may in reality be lower due to the fact the majority of customers are sourced directly and not via intermediaries, with many customers having visited a PCW first. Customers coming through intermediaries are more likely to price walk into higher charges.

11:33 am
JP11:33am

^ That's not from Shore, this is:

JP11:33am

This morning the FCA has published its initial report into the insurance market pricing practices. The overall conclusion is that the market is not working well for many customers and it plans to take actions to improve things. The potential remedies suggested by the FCA include tackling higher prices for those who do not switch; encouraging more people to switch and making firms be clearer and more transparent in their dealings with customers. These are all reasonable goals. Pricing within insurance is, however, complex and a source of competitive advantage for many firms and therefore implementation of some of the proposals could prove difficult.

We expect that those firms more focused on switching (Hastings, Buy at 195p) will be better placed to adjust to the new rules than those with a more traditional customer acquisition model though overall, any additional regulatory oversight on pricing is likely to be negative for profitability in the industry.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

What it means for our investment case. Having been the key driver of the upgrade cycle over the past few years (F18 +53%, F17 +96%), the UK has been in decline the past four Nielsen data points, exacerbated by poor weather and tough comps. Flattish performance in the 4 weeks implies growth required in the UK for the remainder of the year to hit street estimates (+23.5%) looks high to us given current momentum. If street numbers are shaved for the UK for both current and outer years (top and bottom line), this would act as a restraint on multiple expansion in our view. We expect street estimates to fall given that FEVR is a growth stock. Retain our Hold.

tangledodyssey VV75: Are they going to succeed in the US where so many have failed?

11:45 am
BE11:46am

Back to Jefferies.

BE11:46am

UK competitive dynamics. Total UK soft drinks +5.5% after previous 4 wks -4.3%. Schweppes stronger with value +14.2% after August -16.6% reflecting some delisting.
On pricing, August saw FEVR continued negative price/mix -2.3% after August -1.9%, Schweppes saw volume -14.1% (price/mix +0.1%).
Europe - different levels of maturity. Per Nielsen data for Europe ex UK, implied growth in 2018 was +18% vs company reported growth of +24%. As the region gains scale we believe Nielsen is becoming a more reliable proxy for company growth. Per Nielsen, Europe ex UK September +16.8% (August -2.9%, July +20.5%) with YTD running at +10%.

2s10s Do whisky mix with anything? Never see it in cocktail recipes.
2s10s *Does* whisky ...
marktime Like JD + coke. US whisky I mean, not the real stuff
BE11:47am

US growth accelerating. US (17% of sales) 1H +24% reflects off-trade distribution gains across national accounts Target, Kroger & Walmart and regional chains e.g., Publix. On trade new account wins with SGWS under a "fast start initiative" and a broad range of co-promo activities. Elderflower & Mediterranean greater than 50% sales and distribution growth. JP11:55am

t hasn’t been much of a fun run for markets this week and today we welcome in another payrolls Friday. After the two big ISM misses this week including yesterday’s services miss – which we’ll come to shortly - arguably this has become one of the most anticipated employment reports for a long time.The market has swiftly repriced to 22bps of cuts for October’s Fed meeting versus 10bps this time last week. So we haven’t quite got a full cut priced in but clearly we’ve seen a big step change in expectations this week given the data and even an in-line payrolls reading today shouldn’t do much to change the narrative. The consensus for today is for a 145k payrolls print which follows 130k in August with the range amongst the survey participants on Bloomberg anywhere from 85k to 185k.

Our economists are below market at 125k however they note that this could again be boosted by Census workers, which is why it will be critical for market participants to focus on private payrolls (100k forecast vs. 130k consensus and 96k previously). A payroll print in line with our colleagues’ forecast should have the effect of raising the unemployment rate a tenth to 3.8%. Note that similar to August, the consensus forecast for private payrolls has missed the initial print in four out of the last five Septembers by an average of 44k. The median miss during this period has been an even larger 64k. Indeed, if our team’s below consensus forecast is realised, the Fed’s characterisation of the labour market as “strong” could be questioned. As far as the rest of the report is concerned, earnings are expected to rise +0.3% mom and participation rate to hold steady at 63.2%.

11:55 am
JP11:55am

So the tee up for today’s data came in the form of a much weaker than expected ISM non-manufacturing (52.6 vs. 55.0 expected). That’s the lowest level and biggest miss since August 2016. Apart from this one low reading in 2016, you’d have to go back to 2012 to get a lower number. However it was the employment component that most were focusing on and like the equivalent sub component of the manufacturing data earlier this week, it didn’t make for great reading after dropping 2.7pts to 50.4 and the lowest since February 2014. This has historically been a leading indicator for private payrolls so points at some real downside risk to payrolls over the coming months even if it doesn’t show up today.

The immediate reaction in markets to the data was a big rally across rates. Indeed 2y and 10y yields rallied the best part of 10bps and 7bps immediately and eventually closed last night near the lows at -9.0bps and -6.5bps respectively. The rally at the short end did mean the 2s10s curve steepened however and at 14.4bps is now at the steepest since early August. It was a similar story across other bond markets where in Europe 10y Bunds traded down to -0.590% (-4.3bps). Similarly Gold (+0.43%) turned in a third consecutive positive session.

BornCynic No more Mr Collins in the FT. What happened there BE?
JP11:55am

In contrast to bonds, equities experienced more intraday volatility. Most markets promptly sold off as soon as the data was released, with S&P 500 down as much as -1.11% at the lows, however it clawed back to end up an impressive +0.81%.There were two, now-familiar catalysts driving the rebound: positive trade rhetoric and dovish Fed expectations. On the trade front, President Trump spoke optimistically about next week’s planned meeting between his team and Chinese Vice Premier Liu He. The NASDAQ and Philly semiconductor indexes were down a similar amount as the S&P 500 at the lows (-1.09% and -1.12% respectively), but they rebounded even more strongly to end +1.12% and +1.71%, consistent with their outsized trade exposure. Meanwhile, financials (+0.16%) lagged significantly as bond yields dropped and expectations for a near-term Fed rate cut solidified. The VIX traded at an intraday high of 21.44 but ultimately settled down to close back at 19.1, while in Europe the STOXX 600 closed only -0.02% lower. Meanwhile US HY credit spreads were +12bps wider and Oil fell -0.61%. That means oil is now down for 8 sessions in a row – the longest run since last November – and amazingly is trading $11 lower than the post drone strike intraday highs last month and -4.61% below where we were just before the attac

BE11:58am

In the end September saw markets finish up for the month, with MSCI World up 1.9% in September (in US$) and just about in the black for Q3, with a 0.1% gain. The year-to-date numbers, flattered by the collapse in Q4 2018, show MSCI World up 15.7% so far in 2019.

Beneath the surface there was significant rotation, with a dramatic turnaround in Quality vs Value stock performance that saw Quality stocks give back 10% points of outperformance in just a matter of eight trading days at the beginning of the month and a general bounce back in the more cyclical parts of the equity markets (Japan had its best month since September last year). Whilst the turnaround for Value stocks (and more cyclical assets generally) was brutal, the reason was fairly simple: sovereign bond yields started going back up, having fallen dramatically during August - see left-hand chart below. While bond yields were falling in August, we heard few complaints, with everyone defensively positioned and investors were making money. But as bond markets began to fall and Quality and Growth stocks gave way to Value, there was an outcry!

BE11:58am

We have long warned about the danger of an equity market propelled higher by lower bond yields, itself a harbinger of greater economic uncertainty. Many argue that low bond yields justify higher stock valuations, but in a bear market ALL stocks tend to lose money irrespective of their relative cyclicality. So investors are playing a game of chicken: hoping lower bond yields do not lead to a recession, but equally that the global economy remains sufficiently moribund to not cause bond yields to rise and negatively impact expensive defensive and growth stock valuations.

Quality vs Value stock valuations are entirely consistent with this bearish message, what is inconsistent is that equity markets themselves are normally down - not up, or in the very least far more volatile. The inconsistency in the global equity market is then not so much that Value stocks are so cheap or bond yields so low, but why overall equity investors appear to be both ignoring the probability that a recession will actually turn up, while at the same time remaining poorly positioned if we actually do get some economic good news!

The Global game is on: Initiating coverage on European and US Sporting Goods
Sporting Goods has seen long-term outperformance: GDP+ growth fuelled by emerging markets,
categories like womenswear and athleisure, mind and market share concentration, and channel
shift. Still, mindful of currency headwinds and market rotation risk, we take a selective approach,
preferring JD Sports and Puma (+) to Adidas (=) or Nike (-).
Superior athletes playing on a near-perfect pitch
In contrast to our General Retail coverage, structural trends are unambiguously positive. Demand
growth outpaces GDP, with major brands gaining share. In the footsteps run by the luxury
companies, a shift to direct (mainly online) is capturing more of the profit pool and adding c.30bps
pa to margins.
Even star players should beware of rotation
The stocks have benefitted from the ‘Nifty’ shift (sales growth, quality, price momentum, low
volatility), with relative re-rating adding to earnings growth. In a ‘Shifty’ world, all could de-rate.

BornCynic Thanks BE / JP / ROTR - enjoy the weekend.
BE12:01pm

marathon not a sprint: ESG and remuneration
Drawing on our proprietary Survey of Shoppers, we examine customer perceptions of and brand
positioning on ESG. While moving up the agenda, it is not yet material in management
remuneration. We also note that Adidas’s management has few incentives to beat consensus.
The teams are easy on the eye, but who to pick?
Nike faces the greatest currency pressures on our hedging analysis for the next two years (-
220bps vs. Puma -190bps; Adidas -90bps) and has the highest terminal margin and the greatest
amount of margin expansion priced in. Implicit assumptions for Puma seem most attainable,
given its potential for channel shift and positioning in womenswear, while premium-positioned JD
is likely to continue to benefit from increasingly selective wholesale distribution. Adidas is building
for the future and we do not expect positive earnings revisions in the near term.

 Green shoots of progress in Food offset by lack of progress in
Clothing & Home (C&H), now c12-18 months behind plan

BE12:04pm

[W]we focus on the C&H division and three key issues:
1. An established and multi-year decline in Clothing and Home LFL sales:
This means any changes to the underlying offer will take time to gain traction
with consumers and are still dependent on improvements in product planning,
in-season execution, and stock management to address the limitations of its
traditional, long lead-time supply chain.
2. M&S has yet to develop a point of difference on product: M&S has fallen
short of the ‘contemporary and wearable fashion’ aspirations key to accessing
mainstream customers to which it aspires. This is compounded by ‘fit and
buying’ ratios that, while well suited to M&S typically older customers, fails to
reflect mainstream market demand.
3. Mainstream apparel market is getting more and more competitive: Given
the structural shift in spending trends to online that has impacted wider sector
profitability, and resulting capacity withdrawal, M&S is pitched against a
spectrum of larger, more relevant, and better invested fast-fashion peers.
